arxiv \excludeversiontac

Network-aware Recommender System
via Online Feedback Optimization

Sanjay Chandrasekaran ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Giulia De Pasquale ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Giuseppe Belgioioso ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ and Florian D√∂rfler S. Chandrasekaran, G. De Pasquale, F. D√∂rfler are with the Automatic Control Laboratory, Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, ETH Z√ºrich, Physikstrasse 3 8092 Z√ºrich, Switzerland (e-mails: {schandraseka,degiulia,doerfler}@ethz.ch). G. Belgioioso is with the Division of Decision and Control Systems (DCS) at KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Malvinas v√§g 10, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden (e-mail: giubel@kth.se). This work was partially supported by the SNSF via NCCR Automation (Grant Number 180545) and by the Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program (WASP) funded by the Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation.
Abstract

Personalized content on social platforms can exacerbate negative phenomena such as polarization, partly due to the feedback interactions between recommendations and the users. In this paper, we present a control-theoretic recommender system that explicitly accounts for this feedback loop to mitigate polarization. Our approach extends online feedback optimization ‚Äì a control paradigm for steady-state optimization of dynamical systems ‚Äì to develop a recommender system that trades off users engagement and polarization reduction, while relying solely on online click data. We establish theoretical guarantees for optimality and stability of the proposed design and validate its effectiveness via numerical experiments with a user population governed by Friedkin‚ÄìJohnsen dynamics. Our results show these ‚Äúnetwork-aware‚Äù recommendations can significantly reduce polarization while maintaining high levels of user engagement.

{IEEEkeywords}

Recommender systems, networked control systems, opinion dynamics, non-convex optimization.

1 Introduction

Online social platforms use recommender systems to provide users with tailored content to maximize engagement over the platform. To do so, recommender systems exploit techniques, such as content-based filtering [1] and collaborative filtering [2], that combine information personalization, popularity and similarity of interests with other users. A significant drawback of content personalization is related to the amplification phenomenon [3], associated with the feedback loop that arises between recommended content and user preferences. Amplification leads to misinformation spread [4], filter bubbles [5], bias exacerbation [6] and, ultimately, polarization [7, 8]. Motivated by these challenges, we consider instead recommender systems inspired by control-theoretic principles that have the potential of explicitly accounting for the feedback interplay between recommendations and user interests to mitigate polarization. Our goals are to develop a systems-theory-based recommender design to understand i)¬†the impact of recommendations on user opinions, and ii)¬†how recommender systems should depart from engagement maximization to mitigate polarization. We approach the problem by building upon the systems-theory perspective of recommender systems pioneered in [9, 10] and by leveraging on online feedback optimization (OFO) [11] ‚Äì an emerging control paradigm for steady-state optimization of dynamical systems. Specifically, we aim at designing a recommender system as a dynamic feedback controller that mitigates polarization by providing users personalized content, using solely implicit feedback from their online click data, as illustrated in Figure 1.

Related Work

Recommender systems. Most of the literature on recommender systems relies on static methods (such as matrix factorization) and neglects the dynamic nature of the feedback interactions between the users and the online platforms [12]. In contrast, our work develops along a more recent systems-theory perspective on recommender systems [9, 10], where the feedback interaction between social platform and recommender systems is made explicit. In [9], the recommender system provides only extreme positions to the users based on their clicking history. The authors show that when confirmation bias [13] ‚Äì the tendency to engage with content that aligns with prior beliefs ‚Äì is the sole factor driving clicks, their recommender system promotes opinion polarization. The recommender design proposed in [14] alternates between exploitation and exploration by either providing news which more closely align with the users‚Äô beliefs or exploring new content. The authors show that shifts in the opinions at the individual level do not necessarily reflect in the opinion distribution of the population. In [15], the recommender system is modeled as an artificial user within the social platform, providing news content at minimum distance from all users opinions to promote engagement. This study investigates how such a recommender system can affect opinion dynamics across the network. In [10], the focus is on the interplay between a single user, the recommender system, and harmful content. The authors seek recommendation policies that balance maximizing the click-through rate (CTR) and mitigate harm. Their findings suggest that to properly mitigate harm, it is necessary to account for user dynamics. Notably, most of these studies focus solely on individual-user designs, where recommendations are tailored to each user in isolation, without explicitly accounting for the broader influence of social interactions. However, social interactions are well-known to be a crucial factor in shaping opinions over a connected population [16, 17, 18].

Online feedback optimization. Most OFO controllers are based on first-order optimization algorithms [11], and their deployment require real-time access to the states of the plant, an explicit knowledge of its input-output sensitivity (or a closed approximation), and a closed-form expression of the gradient of the control objective. However, some recent extensions [19, 20, 21, 22, 23] have relaxed some of these stringent requirements. Specifically, [19] proposes to estimate the input-output sensitivity of the plant from real-time state measurements using recursive-least square; while [20] achieves similar results leveraging historical input-output trajectories and behavioral systems theory. In [21], the authors address the case where exact states measurements cannot be directly accessed, but need to be inferred from perceptual information. Their solution relies on the integration of a neural network component that transform high-dimensional sensory data into state estimates. Similarly, [22] proposes a neural-network solution for the case where a closed-form expression of the gradient is not available. Finally, [23] utilizes a zeroth-order method to estimate the composite gradient directly from online cost function evaluations, eliminating the need for both input-output sensitivity and a closed-form gradient expression. See Table 1 for a comparative overview of these OFO controllers.

Contributions

Unfortunately, existing OFO designs cannot be directly applied to social networks, as recommender systems typically only have access to implicit feedback in the form of click data. Real-time users opinion are inaccessible, social interactions may be hidden due to privacy preferences, and there is no closed-form expression for the expected CTR as it depends on unknown users clicking behavior ‚Äì namely, their tendencies or pattern when interacting with recommended items.

In this paper, we address these challenges by integrating auxiliary estimation blocks into a projected-gradient OFO controller to compensate for the missing information, thereby enabling online feedback optimization in social networks. Specifically, we estimate opinions and clicking behaviour using supervised learning, sensitivity using Kalman filtering and gradients using zero-order methods.

Unlike most system-theory-based recommender system designs in the literature, our proposed algorithm is network-aware, namely, it leverages on users‚Äô social interactions to better mitigate undesired population phenomena such as polarization, while maintaining high levels of engagement.

Our contribution is threefold:

  1. (i)

    We propose a novel OFO-based recommender system algorithm that steers a social network towards steady-state opinion profiles that balance between maximizing overall click-through rate and minimizing polarization. Our design is agnostic about real-time opinions of the users, their network interactions and clicking behavior, and solely relies on click data measured online.

  2. (ii)

    We establish closed-loop stability guarantees of the recommender system-social network interconnection with respect to locally-optimal solutions of the steady-state control objective, assuming exponential stability of the opinion dynamics and other mild technical conditions.

  3. (iii)

    We validate the proposed recommender system through numerical simulations on a social network where user opinions are governed by an extended version of the Friedkin‚ÄìJohnsen (FJ) dynamics [9], which incorporates the influence of recommended content. Our results demonstrate that network-awareness plays a crucial role in reducing opinion polarization in social platforms.

Outline

In Section 2, we formulate the recommender objectives as a steady-state control problem. In Section 3, we describe the recommender design using OFO. Section 4 present numerical simulations to evaluate the performance of our algorithm and highlight the benefits of network-awareness. Finally, Section 5 summarizes our findings and concludes the paper.

We now state some preliminary lemmas and definitions that are recurrently used in this manuscript.

Definition 1 (Minimal modulus of continuity[24])

Let h:ùí≥‚Üí‚Ñù:‚Ñé‚Üíùí≥‚Ñùh:\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R}italic_h : caligraphic_X ‚Üí blackboard_R be a continuous function over a bounded set ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. The minimal modulus of continuity of h‚Ñéhitalic_h on ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is defined as

œâh(Œ≥):=sup{|h(x)‚àíh(y)|:x,y‚ààùí≥,‚à•x‚àíy‚à•‚àû‚â§Œ≥}.\omega_{h}(\gamma):=\mathrm{sup}\Big{\{}|h(x)-h(y)|:x,y\in\mathcal{X},\lVert x% -y\rVert_{\infty}\leq\gamma\Big{\}}.italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ≥ ) := roman_sup { | italic_h ( italic_x ) - italic_h ( italic_y ) | : italic_x , italic_y ‚àà caligraphic_X , ‚à• italic_x - italic_y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_Œ≥ } .
Definition 2 (Persistently exciting input [25])

The signal u‚àà‚Ñùnùë¢superscript‚Ñùùëõu\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_u ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is said to be persistently exciting of order nùëõnitalic_n if there exists a time span S>0ùëÜ0S>0italic_S > 0 such that for all k>0ùëò0k>0italic_k > 0, the matrix formed by the columns uk+i‚àà‚Ñùnsuperscriptùë¢ùëòùëñsuperscript‚Ñùùëõu^{k+i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for i‚àà{0,1,‚Ä¶‚Å¢S}ùëñ01‚Ä¶ùëÜi\in\{0,1,\ldots S\}italic_i ‚àà { 0 , 1 , ‚Ä¶ italic_S } has full rank, i.e. Rank‚Å¢[uk‚Å¢uk+1‚Å¢‚Ä¶‚Å¢uk+S]=nRankdelimited-[]superscriptùë¢ùëòsuperscriptùë¢ùëò1‚Ä¶superscriptùë¢ùëòùëÜùëõ\mathrm{Rank}[u^{k}\ u^{k+1}\ \ldots\ u^{k+S}]=nroman_Rank [ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä¶ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = italic_n.

Definition 3 (Global Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤-smoothness [26])

A continuously differentiable map Œ¶:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:Œ¶‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñù\Phi:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}roman_Œ¶ : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R is globally Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤-smooth if its gradient ‚àáŒ¶‚àáŒ¶\nabla\Phi‚àá roman_Œ¶ is globally Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤-Lipschitz.

Lemma 1 (Properties of Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤-smooth functions [26])

Given a globally Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤-smooth map Œ¶:‚Ñùn‚Üí‚Ñù:Œ¶‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ‚Ñù\Phi:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}roman_Œ¶ : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R, then Œ¶‚Å¢(x1)‚àíŒ¶‚Å¢(x2)‚àí‚àáŒ¶‚ä§‚Å¢(x2)‚Å¢(x1‚àíx2)‚â§12‚Å¢Œ≤‚Å¢‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•2Œ¶subscriptùë•1Œ¶subscriptùë•2‚àásuperscriptŒ¶topsubscriptùë•2subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•212ùõΩsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•22\Phi(x_{1})-\Phi(x_{2})-\nabla\Phi^{\top}(x_{2})(x_{1}-x_{2})\leq\frac{1}{2}% \beta\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\rVert^{2}roman_Œ¶ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Œ¶ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ‚àá roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_Œ≤ ‚à• italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, if Œ¶Œ¶\Phiroman_Œ¶ is twice continuously-differentiable, then ‚à•‚àá2Œ¶‚à•‚â§Œ≤delimited-‚à•‚à•superscript‚àá2Œ¶ùõΩ\lVert\nabla^{2}\Phi\rVert\leq\beta‚à• ‚àá start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ ‚à• ‚â§ italic_Œ≤.

2 Problem setup

2.1 Social Network Modelling

We consider a recommender system for a social network consisting of nùëõnitalic_n users, indexed by i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n]italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ] that makes sequential, personalized recommendations. User opinions are collected into a vector x‚àà[‚àí1,1]nùë•superscript11ùëõx\in[-1,1]^{n}italic_x ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n]italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ], denoting the opinion of the iùëñiitalic_i-th user. The users‚Äô opinions evolve as

xk+1=f‚Å¢(xk,pk,d),superscriptùë•ùëò1ùëìsuperscriptùë•ùëòsuperscriptùëùùëòùëëx^{k+1}=f(x^{k},p^{k},d),italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) , (1)

where p‚àà[‚àí1, 1]nùëùsuperscript11ùëõp\in[-1,\ 1]^{n}italic_p ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT refers to the positions that the recommended article takes on, whose iùëñiitalic_i-th entry is the position provided to the iùëñiitalic_i-th user, d‚àà[‚àí1, 1]nùëësuperscript11ùëõd\in[-1,\ 1]^{n}italic_d ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represents an external influence to the platform, e.g., television, newspapers or a personal bias, and f:([‚àí1, 1]n)3‚Üí[‚àí1, 1]n:ùëì‚Üísuperscriptsuperscript11ùëõ3superscript11ùëõf:([-1,\ 1]^{n})^{3}\to[-1,\ 1]^{n}italic_f : ( [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT encodes the influence of interactions among users. We assume there is a single topic of discussion or issue, on the platform. For the sake of illustration, if the issue is polarizing, then, a recommendation with position p=+1ùëù1p=+1italic_p = + 1 (‚àí11-1- 1) can be interpreted as news strongly in support of (against) the issue.

The following assumption ensures that the dynamics (1) are well-posed and admit a steady-state mapping.

Assumption 1 (Well-posedness)

The following hold:

  1. (i)

    The dynamics (1) are forward invariant in [‚àí1, 1]nsuperscript11ùëõ[-1,\ 1]^{n}[ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e.,

    x0,p0,d0‚àà[‚àí1, 1]n‚áíxk‚àà[‚àí1, 1]n,‚àÄk‚àà‚Ñï0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptùë•0superscriptùëù0superscriptùëë0superscript11ùëõ‚áísuperscriptùë•ùëòsuperscript11ùëõfor-allùëòsubscript‚Ñï0x^{0},p^{0},d^{0}\in[-1,\ 1]^{n}\,\Rightarrow\,x^{k}\in[-1,\ 1]^{n},\;\forall k% \in\mathbb{N}_{0}.italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚áí italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ‚àÄ italic_k ‚àà blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
  2. (ii)

    The dynamics (1) are uniformly exponentially stable with constant p,dùëùùëëp,ditalic_p , italic_d, and admit a unique steady-state map h:([‚àí1, 1]n)2‚Üí[‚àí1, 1]n:‚Ñé‚Üísuperscriptsuperscript11ùëõ2superscript11ùëõh:\big{(}[-1,\ 1]^{n}\big{)}^{2}\rightarrow[-1,\ 1]^{n}italic_h : ( [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying

    h‚Å¢(p,d)=f‚Å¢(h‚Å¢(p,d),p,d),‚àÄp,d‚àà[‚àí1, 1]n.formulae-sequence‚Ñéùëùùëëùëì‚Ñéùëùùëëùëùùëëfor-allùëùùëësuperscript11ùëõh(p,d)=f(h(p,d),p,d),\quad\forall p,d\in[-1,\ 1]^{n}.italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) = italic_f ( italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) , italic_p , italic_d ) , ‚àÄ italic_p , italic_d ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
  3. (iii)

    The map h‚Å¢(p,d)‚Ñéùëùùëëh(p,d)italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) is continuously-differentiable and L‚àílimit-fromùêøL-italic_L -Lipschitz [26] with respect to pùëùpitalic_p. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square‚ñ°

This assumption can be easily adopted for a wide array of renowned opinion dynamics models, such as De-Groot model [17], FJ model [16], and polar opinion dynamics model [18], among others, for which the influence of a recommender system can be, in principle, included. For an extensive list of such models, we refer the reader to the survey [27]. Traditionally, in fact, these models consider social interactions and prejudice as the only driving forces behind opinion formation. Nonetheless, recommendations on contentious topics provably influence user opinions [9], underscoring the need to include their influence in the opinion dynamics. Next, we illustrate an example of how the FJ model, one of the most widely used opinion dynamics models across different communities [28, 29, 30, 31, 32, 9, 10], can be extended to capture the effects of the recommender on networked users.

Example 1 (Extended Friedkin‚ÄìJohnsen model)

The opinions evolve according to

xk+1=(In‚àíŒìp‚àíŒìd)‚Å¢A‚Å¢xk+Œìp‚Å¢pk+Œìd‚Å¢d,superscriptùë•ùëò1subscriptùêºùëõsubscriptŒìùëùsubscriptŒìùëëùê¥superscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptŒìùëùsuperscriptùëùùëòsubscriptŒìùëëùëëx^{k+1}=(I_{n}-\Gamma_{p}-\Gamma_{d})Ax^{k}+\Gamma_{p}p^{k}+\Gamma_{d}d,italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_A italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d , (2)

where Œìd,ŒìpsubscriptŒìùëësubscriptŒìùëù\Gamma_{d},\Gamma_{p}roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positive diagonal matrices such that Œìp+Œìd‚™ØInprecedes-or-equalssubscriptŒìùëùsubscriptŒìùëësubscriptùêºùëõ\Gamma_{p}+\Gamma_{d}\preceq I_{n}roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚™Ø italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, describing the impact of dùëëditalic_d and pùëùpitalic_p over the opinions, and Aùê¥Aitalic_A is a row-stochastic adjacency matrix encoding the social interconnections of the users. The dynamics (2) are forward-invariant in [‚àí1,1]nsuperscript11ùëõ[-1,1]^{n}[ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since the opinions are a convex combination of x,p,d‚àà[‚àí1,1]nùë•ùëùùëësuperscript11ùëõx,p,d\in[-1,1]^{n}italic_x , italic_p , italic_d ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, for a constant position provided by the recommender system, the steady-state mapping is single-valued, affine (hence, continuously differentiable), and reads as

h‚Å¢(p,d)=(In‚àí(In‚àíŒìp‚àíŒìd)‚Å¢A)‚àí1‚Å¢(Œìp‚Å¢p+Œìd‚Å¢d).‚ÑéùëùùëësuperscriptsubscriptùêºùëõsubscriptùêºùëõsubscriptŒìùëùsubscriptŒìùëëùê¥1subscriptŒìùëùùëùsubscriptŒìùëëùëëh(p,d)=(I_{n}-(I_{n}-\Gamma_{p}-\Gamma_{d})A)^{-1}(\Gamma_{p}p+\Gamma_{d}d).italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ) .

Note that by taking Œìp=OnsubscriptŒìùëùsubscriptùëÇùëõ\Gamma_{p}=O_{n}roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and d=x0ùëësuperscriptùë•0d=x^{0}italic_d = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be an initial bias, the dynamics (2) reduce to the standard FJ model [16]. ‚ñ≥‚ñ≥\triangle‚ñ≥

Engagement of the users over the platform is measured in terms of CTR, measured as number of clicks over number of provided news articles. As common practice in the context of implicit feedback recommender systems [33], for a generic user i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n]italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ] holding an opinion xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we model the probability of iùëñiitalic_i clicking on a recommendation with position pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a random variable cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sampled from a Bernoulli distribution with unknown argument gi‚Å¢(pi,xi)subscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñg_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), i.e. ci‚àº‚Ñ¨‚Å¢(gi‚Å¢(pi,xi))similar-tosubscriptùëêùëñ‚Ñ¨subscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñc_{i}\sim\mathcal{B}(g_{i}(p_{i},x_{i}))italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_B ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). The argument gi‚Å¢(pi,xi)subscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñg_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) represents the clicking behaviour of user iùëñiitalic_i and depends on the user‚Äôs opinion xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well as the position of the recommendation pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We will work under the following regularity assumptions on the clicking behaviour:

Assumption 2 (Clicking behaviour)

The clicking¬†behaviour g‚Å¢(p,x):[‚àí1,1]n√ó[‚àí1,1]n‚Üí[0,1]n:ùëîùëùùë•‚Üísuperscript11ùëõsuperscript11ùëõsuperscript01ùëõg(p,x):[-1,1]^{n}\times[-1,1]^{n}\to[0,1]^{n}italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) : [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is MxsubscriptùëÄùë•M_{x}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT¬†-¬†Lipschitz with respect to xùë•xitalic_x, and LpsubscriptùêøùëùL_{p}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT- and Lxsubscriptùêøùë•L_{x}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-smooth with respect to pùëùpitalic_p and xùë•xitalic_x, respectively. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square‚ñ°

Next, we provide an example of a clicking behaviour.

Example 2 (Extremity confirmation bias [9])

A user i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi~{}\in~{}[n]italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ], holding opinion xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, affected by extremity confirmation bias clicks on a recommendation pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability

ci‚àº‚Ñ¨‚Å¢(12+12‚Å¢xi‚Å¢pi),similar-tosubscriptùëêùëñ‚Ñ¨1212subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùëñc_{i}\sim\mathcal{B}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}x_{i}p_{i}\right),italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_B ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where the clicking behaviour gi‚Å¢(pi,xi)=12+12‚Å¢xi‚Å¢pisubscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ1212subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùëñg_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}x_{i}p_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT models confirmation bias towards extreme recommendations. In fact, for an opinion xi‚âà¬±1subscriptùë•ùëñplus-or-minus1x_{i}\approx\pm 1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âà ¬± 1 and a position pi‚âà¬±1subscriptùëùùëñplus-or-minus1p_{i}\approx\pm 1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âà ¬± 1 (‚àì1minus-or-plus1\mp 1‚àì 1), the probability of clicking is almost 1111 (00). The click event becomes random as the user position approaches the neutral stance pi‚âà0subscriptùëùùëñ0p_{i}\approx 0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âà 0, highlighting diminished engagement for less polarized content or when recommendations directly counter the user‚Äôs stance on the issue. ‚ñ≥‚ñ≥\triangle‚ñ≥

2.2 Problem formulation

The goal of the recommender system is to provide recommendations that optimize a specific metric, denoted as œÜ‚Å¢(p,x)ùúëùëùùë•\varphi(p,x)italic_œÜ ( italic_p , italic_x ). Typical choices in the literature include maximizing CTR [9, 10], opinion control [34], and polarization mitigation [35]. Deviating from traditional recommender systems, we consider a multi-objective cost function combining engagement maximization and polarization mitigation, given by

œÜ‚Å¢(p,x)=œÜctr‚Å¢(p,x)+Œ≥‚Å¢œÜpol‚Å¢(x),ùúëùëùùë•superscriptùúëctrùëùùë•ùõæsuperscriptùúëpolùë•\varphi(p,x)=\varphi^{\text{ctr}}(p,x)+\gamma\,\varphi^{\text{pol}}(x),italic_œÜ ( italic_p , italic_x ) = italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) + italic_Œ≥ italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , (3)

where Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ is a non-negative trade-off parameter. The engagement-related term in (3) is the CTR, formalized as

œÜctr‚Å¢(p,x)=‚àí‚àëi‚àà[n]ùîºci‚àºùîπ‚Å¢(gi‚Å¢(xi,pi))‚Å¢[ci],superscriptùúëctrùëùùë•subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsubscriptùîºsimilar-tosubscriptùëêùëñùîπsubscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]subscriptùëêùëñ\varphi^{\text{ctr}}(p,x)=-\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{E}_{c_{i}\sim\mathbb{B}(g_{i}% (x_{i},p_{i}))}[\,c_{i}\,],italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) = - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº blackboard_B ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,

where ùîºci‚àºùîπ‚Å¢(gi‚Å¢(xi,pi))‚Å¢[ci]subscriptùîºsimilar-tosubscriptùëêùëñùîπsubscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùëñdelimited-[]subscriptùëêùëñ\mathbb{E}_{c_{i}\sim\mathbb{B}(g_{i}(x_{i},p_{i}))}[\,c_{i}\,]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº blackboard_B ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is the expectation of user iùëñiitalic_i‚Äôs clicking, given their opinion xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a recommendation with position pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The second term in (3), œÜpolsuperscriptùúëpol\varphi^{\rm pol}italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, is a smooth and Lipschitz function that measures opinion polarization. For our algorithm we consider it to be œÜpol‚Å¢(x):=‚àëi‚àà[n]si‚Å¢(x)assignsuperscriptùúëpolùë•subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëñùë•\varphi^{\text{pol}}(x):=\sum_{i\in[n]}s_{i}(x)italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), where sisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT penalizes deviations from the moderate (zero) opinions:

si‚Å¢(xi)={(xi‚àíœµ1)2xi<œµ10œµ1‚â§xi‚â§œµ2(œµ2‚àíxi)2xi>œµ2subscriptùë†ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñcasessuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptitalic-œµ12subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptitalic-œµ10subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptitalic-œµ2superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµ2subscriptùë•ùëñ2subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptitalic-œµ2\displaystyle s_{i}(x_{i})=\begin{cases}(x_{i}-\epsilon_{1})^{2}&x_{i}<% \epsilon_{1}\\ 0&\epsilon_{1}\leq x_{i}\leq\epsilon_{2}\\ (\epsilon_{2}-x_{i})^{2}&x_{i}>\epsilon_{2}\end{cases}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW (4)

Therein, the parameters œµ1‚â§œµ2subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2\epsilon_{1}\leq\epsilon_{2}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are used to control the degree of penalty towards extreme opinions. Specifically, a smaller positive (negative) choice for œµ2subscriptitalic-œµ2\epsilon_{2}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ1\epsilon_{1}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) indicates a higher penalty on extreme positive (negative) opinions. According to [36], the metric in (4) falls in the class of polarization spread, indicating how extreme the opinions are. Note that, for œµ1=œµ2=0subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ20\epsilon_{1}=\epsilon_{2}=0italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the term (4) reduces to œÜpol‚Å¢(x)=‚à•x‚à•2superscriptùúëpolùë•superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë•2\varphi^{\text{pol}}(x)=\lVert x\rVert^{2}italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ‚à• italic_x ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, another classic measure for opinion polarization [29].

The recommender system aims at finding the recommendation that drives the user population with dynamics (1) to a steady-state minimizing the multi-objective cost (3):

minimizep,xùëùùë•minimize\displaystyle\underset{p,\,x}{\mathrm{minimize}}start_UNDERACCENT italic_p , italic_x end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_minimize end_ARG œÜ‚Å¢(p,x)ùúëùëùùë•\displaystyle\quad\varphi(p,x)italic_œÜ ( italic_p , italic_x ) (5a)
s.t. x=h‚Å¢(p,d)ùë•‚Ñéùëùùëë\displaystyle\quad x=h(p,d)italic_x = italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) (5b)
p‚àà[‚àí1,1]nùëùsuperscript11ùëõ\displaystyle\quad p\in[-1,1]^{n}italic_p ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (5c)

This problem is uncertain and potentially non-convex, since the analytical form of the clicking behaviour is unknown and likely complex. Likewise, the opinion dynamics (1) are unknown. If the opinion dynamics in (1) and the clicking behavior gisubscriptùëîùëñg_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were known, and an accurate prediction of external influences dùëëditalic_d were available, then one could aim to solve (5) offline. However, in practice, none of these information is readily available, and the recommender system can provide personalized positions solely relying on clicks {cik}superscriptsubscriptùëêùëñùëò\{c_{i}^{k}\}{ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }.

Remark 1

Equation (5b) reflects the assumption that users‚Äô opinions reach steady-state before the recommender system takes action. This approach is in line with most of the existing works on recommender systems that incorporates preference dynamics [10, 9, 37, 6, 38], where recommendation decisions are made based on the steady-state behavior of the users‚Äô preferences under the model.

Our feedback control problem is formally stated as follows:

Problem 1

Design a feedback controller p‚Å¢(c)ùëùùëêp(c)italic_p ( italic_c ) so that (1) converges to a solution (p‚àó,x‚àó)superscriptùëùsuperscriptùë•(p^{*},x^{*})( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of the optimization problem (5), assuming that only clicks ciksuperscriptsubscriptùëêùëñùëòc_{i}^{k}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are available. The clicking behaviours gi‚Å¢(pi,xi)subscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñg_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), steady-state map h‚Å¢(p,d)‚Ñéùëùùëëh(p,d)italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ), the opinion dynamics (1), external influence dùëëditalic_d are unknown, and the real-time opinions xùë•xitalic_x are not measurable.

3 Recommender system design

We approach Problem 1 by designing a dynamic feedback controller inspired by the projected-gradient descent algorithm in [39, Section 3A]. The resulting recommender system dynamically generates recommendations as

pk+1=Œ†[‚àí1,1]n‚Å¢[pk‚àíŒ∑‚Å¢Œ¶‚Å¢(pk,xk+1)],‚àÄk‚àà‚Ñïformulae-sequencesuperscriptùëùùëò1subscriptŒ†superscript11ùëõdelimited-[]superscriptùëùùëòùúÇŒ¶superscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptùë•ùëò1for-allùëò‚Ñïp^{k+1}=\Pi_{[-1,1]^{n}}\big{[}p^{k}-\eta\,\Phi(p^{k},x^{k+1})\big{]},\quad% \forall k\in\mathbb{N}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Œ† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œ∑ roman_Œ¶ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] , ‚àÄ italic_k ‚àà blackboard_N (6)

where Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ is a tunable controller gain, and

Œ¶‚Å¢(p,x):=‚àápœÜ‚Å¢(p,x)+‚àáph‚Å¢(p,d)‚ä§‚Å¢‚àáxœÜ‚Å¢(p,x)assignŒ¶ùëùùë•subscript‚àáùëùùúëùëùùë•subscript‚àáùëù‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëëtopsubscript‚àáùë•ùúëùëùùë•\displaystyle\Phi(p,x):=\nabla_{p}\varphi(p,x)+\nabla_{p}h(p,d)^{\top}\nabla_{% x}\varphi(p,x)roman_Œ¶ ( italic_p , italic_x ) := ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÜ ( italic_p , italic_x ) + ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÜ ( italic_p , italic_x ) (7)

represents the gradient obtained by applying the chain-rule of differentiation to the cost œÜ‚Å¢(p,x)ùúëùëùùë•\varphi(p,x)italic_œÜ ( italic_p , italic_x ) in (5), with opinions at steady state, i.e., x=h‚Å¢(p,d)ùë•‚Ñéùëùùëëx=h(p,d)italic_x = italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ). In practice, evaluating the gradient (7) at each sampling instant kùëòkitalic_k requires access to:

  1. (i)

    Real-time users‚Äô opinions xksuperscriptùë•ùëòx^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT;

  2. (ii)

    Sensitivity mapping ‚àáph‚Å¢(p,d)subscript‚àáùëù‚Ñéùëùùëë\nabla_{p}h(p,d)‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ); and

  3. (iii)

    Gradients ‚àápœÜ‚Å¢(p,x)subscript‚àáùëùùúëùëùùë•\nabla_{p}\varphi(p,x)‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÜ ( italic_p , italic_x ) and ‚àáxœÜ‚Å¢(p,x)subscript‚àáùë•ùúëùëùùë•\nabla_{x}\varphi(p,x)‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÜ ( italic_p , italic_x ).

None of the above information is readily available, making a direct implementation of the recommender design (6) impractical. In fact, the users‚Äô opinion are not accessible in practice, their dynamics are generally unknown (and so are their sensitivities), and the gradients ‚àápœÜsubscript‚àáùëùùúë\nabla_{p}\varphi‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÜ, ‚àáxœÜsubscript‚àáùë•ùúë\nabla_{x}\varphi‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÜ depend on the users‚Äô clicking behaviour g‚Å¢(p,x)ùëîùëùùë•g(p,x)italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ), which is also unknown. Instead, we have access only to the users‚Äô clicks {ck}superscriptùëêùëò\{c^{k}\}{ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } from which we compute their CTRs yik:=‚àët=k‚àíTkcit/(T+1),‚àÄk‚â•Tformulae-sequenceassignsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòùëáùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëêùëñùë°ùëá1for-allùëòùëáy_{i}^{k}:=\sum_{t=k-T}^{k}c_{i}^{t}/(T+1),\forall\ k\geq Titalic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = italic_k - italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( italic_T + 1 ) , ‚àÄ italic_k ‚â• italic_T, for some time window TùëáTitalic_T. This can be regarded as an approximation of the expectation of a click, i.e., ùîº‚Å¢[‚Ñ¨‚Å¢(g‚Å¢(p,x))]=g‚Å¢(p,x)ùîºdelimited-[]‚Ñ¨ùëîùëùùë•ùëîùëùùë•\mathbb{E}\big{[}\mathcal{B}(g(p,x))\big{]}=g(p,x)blackboard_E [ caligraphic_B ( italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) ) ] = italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ).

To cope with these challenges, we augment the controller (6) with three auxiliary blocks associated with users‚Äô opinions, sensitivity, and clicking behaviour estimates in real-time. Specifically, we structure the design on three levels:

  1. (i)

    Estimation of real-time opinions and users‚Äô clicking behaviour via supervised learning;

  2. (ii)

    Online sensitivity learning via Kalman filtering; and

  3. (iii)

    Gradient estimation via a forward difference method.

The resulting control architecture is illustrated in Fig.¬†2 and summarized in Algorithm 1. In the following three sections, we describe each level.

3.1 Level I: Opinions & Clicking Behaviour Estimation

The opinions and clicking behaviours are estimated using an Artificial Neural Network (ANN).

We estimate the opinions by relying on implicit feedback from the users, i.e., the CTR y‚âàùîº‚Å¢[‚Ñ¨‚Å¢(g‚Å¢(p,x))]ùë¶ùîºdelimited-[]‚Ñ¨ùëîùëùùë•y\approx\mathbb{E}\big{[}\mathcal{B}(g(p,x))\big{]}italic_y ‚âà blackboard_E [ caligraphic_B ( italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) ) ] of the users on recommendations with position pùëùpitalic_p. Thus, we seek a map to extract the opinions from the clicks and the positions, x=Œ≤‚Å¢(y,p)ùë•ùõΩùë¶ùëùx=\beta(y,p)italic_x = italic_Œ≤ ( italic_y , italic_p ). To bound the resulting opinions and clicking behaviour estimation error from the ANN, we work under the following regularity assumptions [21, 40].

Assumption 3 (Opinion & Clicking behaviour maps)

We assume that

  1. i)

    There exists a continuous map Œ≤:[0,1]n√ó[‚àí1,1]n‚Üí[‚àí1,1]n:ùõΩ‚Üísuperscript01ùëõsuperscript11ùëõsuperscript11ùëõ\beta:[0,1]^{n}\times[-1,1]^{n}\to[-1,1]^{n}italic_Œ≤ : [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is such that Œ≤‚Å¢(y,p)=x+Œ∏‚Å¢(x)ùõΩùë¶ùëùùë•ùúÉùë•\beta(y,p)=x+\theta(x)italic_Œ≤ ( italic_y , italic_p ) = italic_x + italic_Œ∏ ( italic_x ) with ‚à•Œ∏‚Å¢(x)‚à•‚â§Œ∏xdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùúÉùë•subscriptùúÉùë•\lVert\theta(x)\rVert\leq\theta_{x}‚à• italic_Œ∏ ( italic_x ) ‚à• ‚â§ italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for all x‚ààùí≥‚äÜ[‚àí1,1]nùë•ùí≥superscript11ùëõx\in\mathcal{X}\subseteq[-1,1]^{n}italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_X ‚äÜ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Œ∏x<‚àûsubscriptùúÉùë•\theta_{x}<\inftyitalic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ‚àû; moreover, the image Œ≤‚Å¢(ùí¥,ùí´)ùõΩùí¥ùí´\beta(\mathcal{Y},\mathcal{P})italic_Œ≤ ( caligraphic_Y , caligraphic_P ) is compact for any ùí¥‚äÜ[0,1]n,ùí´‚äÜ[‚àí1,1]nformulae-sequenceùí¥superscript01ùëõùí´superscript11ùëõ\mathcal{Y}\subseteq[0,1]^{n},\mathcal{P}\subseteq[-1,1]^{n}caligraphic_Y ‚äÜ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_P ‚äÜ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  2. ii)

    There exists a constant Œ±y<‚àûsubscriptùõºùë¶\alpha_{y}<\inftyitalic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ‚àû such that the composite function takes the form g‚Å¢(p,Œ≤‚Å¢(y,p))=y+‚àáxg‚Å¢(p,x)‚ä§‚Å¢Œ∏‚Å¢(x)+Œ±‚Å¢(y)ùëîùëùùõΩùë¶ùëùùë¶subscript‚àáùë•ùëîsuperscriptùëùùë•topùúÉùë•ùõºùë¶g(p,\beta(y,p))=y+\nabla_{x}g(p,x)^{\top}\theta(x)+\alpha(y)italic_g ( italic_p , italic_Œ≤ ( italic_y , italic_p ) ) = italic_y + ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ ( italic_x ) + italic_Œ± ( italic_y ), with ‚à•Œ±‚Å¢(y)‚à•‚â§Œ±ydelimited-‚à•‚à•ùõºùë¶subscriptùõºùë¶\lVert\alpha(y)\rVert\leq\alpha_{y}‚à• italic_Œ± ( italic_y ) ‚à• ‚â§ italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for all y‚ààùí¥ùë¶ùí¥y\in\mathcal{Y}italic_y ‚àà caligraphic_Y. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square‚ñ°

Assumption 3 i) guarantees the map Œ≤‚Å¢(y,p)ùõΩùë¶ùëù\beta(y,p)italic_Œ≤ ( italic_y , italic_p ) to provide an estimate on users‚Äô opinions upper bounded by Œ∏xsubscriptùúÉùë•\theta_{x}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Similarly, Assumption 3 ii), guarantees the (opinion) map Œ≤‚Å¢(y,p)ùõΩùë¶ùëù\beta(y,p)italic_Œ≤ ( italic_y , italic_p ) to (implicitly) provide an estimate on clicking behavior upper bounded by Mx‚Å¢Œ∏x+Œ±ysubscriptùëÄùë•subscriptùúÉùë•subscriptùõºùë¶M_{x}\theta_{x}+\alpha_{y}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with MxsubscriptùëÄùë•M_{x}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT resulting from Assumption 2. We will qualitatively describe how these upper bound errors can be tightened in Section 3.4.

In the remainder of this section, we denote by ùí≥p,ùí≥x‚àà[‚àí1,1]n√óm,ùí≥y‚àà[0,1]n√ómformulae-sequencesubscriptùí≥ùëùsubscriptùí≥ùë•superscript11ùëõùëösubscriptùí≥ùë¶superscript01ùëõùëö\mathcal{X}_{p},\mathcal{X}_{x}\in[-1,1]^{n\times m},\mathcal{X}_{y}\in[0,1]^{% n\times m}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n √ó italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n √ó italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the data sets of the positions, steady-state opinions, and the CTR used for training of the ANN. The process to acquire the training data is explained in detail in Appendix 5.1.

3.1.1 Opinion Estimation

Here, we describe the training process to estimate Œ≤ùõΩ{\beta}italic_Œ≤ in Assumption 3 using an ANN.

For each user i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n]italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ], the input and output training sets are

[ùí≥pùí≥y,i]‚àà{[‚àí1,1]n√óm[0,1]1√óm},ùí≥x,i‚àà[‚àí1,1]1√óm,formulae-sequencematrixsubscriptùí≥ùëùsubscriptùí≥ùë¶ùëñmatrixsuperscript11ùëõùëösuperscript011ùëösubscriptùí≥ùë•ùëñsuperscript111ùëö\begin{bmatrix}\mathcal{X}_{p}\\ \mathcal{X}_{y,i}\end{bmatrix}\in\begin{Bmatrix}[-1,1]^{n\times m}\\ [0,1]^{1\times m}\end{Bmatrix},\mathcal{X}_{x,i}\in[-1,1]^{1\times m},[ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ‚àà { start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n √ó italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 √ó italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG } , caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 √ó italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

respectively. Given that users interact with each other, the recommendations to users connected to user iùëñiitalic_i will indirectly influence user iùëñiitalic_i‚Äôs opinion xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not directly affected by the CTR of other users. To model this, we design the input layer with n+1ùëõ1n+1italic_n + 1 neurons for each user: nùëõnitalic_n neurons associated with pùëùpitalic_p and one neuron associated with yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The output layer comprises a single neuron to represent xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Additionally, we incorporate an intermediate layer with n+2ùëõ2n+2italic_n + 2 neurons. The intermediate layer employs a hyperbolic tangent activation function tanh‚Å°(x):‚Ñù‚Üí[‚àí1,1]:ùë•‚Üí‚Ñù11\tanh(x):\mathbb{R}\rightarrow[-1,1]roman_tanh ( italic_x ) : blackboard_R ‚Üí [ - 1 , 1 ], while the output layer uses an identity activation function.

Next, we provide an upper bound for the opinion estimation error ex:=h‚Å¢(p,d)‚àíŒ≤^‚Å¢(y,p)assignsubscriptùëíùë•‚Ñéùëùùëë^ùõΩùë¶ùëùe_{x}:=h(p,d)-\hat{\beta}(y,p)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) - over^ start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_p ), where Œ≤^^ùõΩ\hat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG is the opinion estimate map learned by the neural network.

Lemma 2 (Opinion estimation error)

Under Assumption¬†3, the opinion estimation error is upper bounded as ‚à•ex‚à•‚â§œµxdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëíùë•subscriptitalic-œµùë•\lVert e_{x}\rVert\leq\epsilon_{x}‚à• italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with

Proof 3.1.

3.1.2 Clicking Behaviour Estimation

respectively. Given the recommender system‚Äôs personalization of positions to the user‚Äôs interests, the iùëñiitalic_i-th user‚Äôs CTR yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only depends on their steady-state opinion xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the provided position pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence, we have two input neurons (xi,pisubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùëñx_{i},p_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and one neuron in the output layer (yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Further, we use 3333 intermediate layers with 5555 neurons. The hyperbolic tangent and the identity are used as activation functions at the intermediate layers and the output layer, respectively.

We now derive an upper bound on the resulting clicking behaviour estimation error ey:=g^‚Å¢(p,x^)‚àíg‚Å¢(p,h‚Å¢(p,d))assignsubscriptùëíùë¶^ùëîùëù^ùë•ùëîùëù‚Ñéùëùùëëe_{y}:=\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-g(p,h(p,d))italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ), where x^^ùë•\hat{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG and g^^ùëî\hat{g}over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG represents the opinion and clicking behaviour learned by the ANN.

Lemma 3.2 (Clicking behaviour estimation error).

Under Assumptions 2‚Äì3, the clicking behaviour estimation error is upper-bounded as ‚à•ey‚à•‚â§œµgdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëíùë¶subscriptitalic-œµùëî\lVert e_{y}\rVert\leq\epsilon_{g}‚à• italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with

œµg‚â§n[\displaystyle\epsilon_{g}\leq\sqrt{n}\Big{[}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG [ 3‚Å¢supp‚ààùí≥p,x‚ààùí≥x‚Å¢‚à•g‚Å¢(p,x)‚àíg^‚Å¢(p,x)‚à•‚àû+2‚Å¢supi‚àà[n]‚Å¢œâgi‚Å¢(Œ≥y)+3formulae-sequenceùëùsubscriptùí≥ùëùùë•subscriptùí≥ùë•supsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëîùëùùë•^ùëîùëùùë•limit-from2ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõsupsubscriptùúîsubscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùõæùë¶\displaystyle 3\underset{p\in\mathcal{X}_{p},x\in\mathcal{X}_{x}}{\mathrm{sup}% }\lVert g(p,x)-\hat{g}(p,x)\rVert_{\infty}+2\underset{i\in[n]}{\mathrm{sup}}% \omega_{g_{i}}(\gamma_{y})+3 start_UNDERACCENT italic_p ‚àà caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ‚àà caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG ‚à• italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) - over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , italic_x ) ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 start_UNDERACCENT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ] end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) +
