Proof 3.3.

The proof is similar to that of Lemma 2 and hence is omitted due to space limitation. We refer the interested reader to the extended version of this paper .

{arxiv}
Proof 3.4.

Refer to Appendix 5.3.

The values Œ≥x,Œ≥ysubscriptùõæùë•subscriptùõæùë¶\gamma_{x},\gamma_{y}italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the modulus of continuity are properties of the training set and can be determined before training the ANN. The maximum training error term in Lemmas 2, 3.2 can be ascertained after training the ANN. The values v0,i,w0,isubscriptùë£0ùëñsubscriptùë§0ùëñv_{0,i},w_{0,i}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the bias weights from the penultimate to the final layer in the ANN, which are known after training the ANN.

3.2 Level II: Online Sensitivity Learning

To estimate the sensitivity ‚àáph‚Å¢(p,d)subscript‚àáùëù‚Ñéùëùùëë\nabla_{p}h(p,d)‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) in (7), we develop a Kalman filter, similar to [19]. Given that opinion dynamics and recommendations evolve over time scales that are comparable in magnitude, in order to make our OFO scheme [41] applicable, we introduce an auxiliary mechanism that guarantees time-scale separation between the opinion dynamics and the recommender system updates, see Remark 1.

Note that the input-output sensitivity brings information about interpersonal influence among agents, in fact, if ‚àáphi‚Å¢j‚Å¢(p,d)‚â†0subscript‚àáùëùsubscript‚Ñéùëñùëóùëùùëë0\nabla_{p}h_{ij}(p,d)\neq 0‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_d ) ‚â† 0 it means that the position provided to agent jùëójitalic_j influences agent iùëñiitalic_i‚Äôs opinion, hence jùëójitalic_j and iùëñiitalic_i are connected over the platform. Thus, by estimating the sensitivity we are able to perform network-aware recommendations. We will see later in this manuscript how this turns out to be beneficial in attenuating polarization.

3.2.1 Kalman Filter for Sensitivity Learning

We denote by ‚Ñì‚àà‚Ñùn2‚Ñìsuperscript‚Ñùsuperscriptùëõ2\ell\in\mathbb{R}^{n^{2}}roman_‚Ñì ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the vectorized sensitivity ‚àáph‚Å¢(p,d)‚àà‚Ñùn√ónsubscript‚àáùëù‚Ñéùëùùëësuperscript‚Ñùùëõùëõ\nabla_{p}h(p,d)\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n √ó italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, namely, ‚Ñì:=vec‚Å¢(‚àáph‚Å¢(p,d))assign‚Ñìvecsubscript‚àáùëù‚Ñéùëùùëë\ell:=\textrm{vec}(\nabla_{p}h(p,d))roman_‚Ñì := vec ( ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ), and model the sensitivity dynamics as the following random walk:

‚Ñìk=‚Ñìk‚àí1+wk‚àí1,superscript‚Ñìùëòsuperscript‚Ñìùëò1superscriptùë§ùëò1\ell^{k}=\ell^{k-1}+w^{k-1},roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (10)

where, wk‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0n2,Qk)similar-tosuperscriptùë§ùëòùí©subscript0superscriptùëõ2superscriptùëÑùëòw^{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0_{n^{2}},Q^{k})italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the process noise, with QksuperscriptùëÑùëòQ^{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as its corresponding covariance matrix. The measurement model is

Œî‚Å¢xssk+1,k=Œî‚Å¢p~k,k‚àí1‚Å¢‚Ñìk+vk,Œîsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ssùëò1ùëòŒîsuperscript~ùëùùëòùëò1superscript‚Ñìùëòsuperscriptùë£ùëò\Delta x_{\rm ss}^{k+1,k}=\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,k-1}\ell^{k}+v^{k},roman_Œî italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ss end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Œî over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (11)

where Œî‚Å¢xssk+1,k:=h‚Å¢(pk,d)‚àíh‚Å¢(pk‚àí1,d)assignŒîsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ssùëò1ùëò‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëòùëë‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëò1ùëë\Delta x_{\rm ss}^{k+1,k}:=h(p^{k},d)-h(p^{k-1},d)roman_Œî italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ss end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) - italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) is the change in steady-state opinions for a corresponding change in positions Œî‚Å¢pk,k‚àí1:=pk‚àípk‚àí1assignŒîsuperscriptùëùùëòùëò1superscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptùëùùëò1\Delta p^{k,k-1}:=p^{k}-p^{k-1}roman_Œî italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Œî‚Å¢p~l,m:=Œî‚Å¢(pl,m)‚ä§‚äóIn‚àà‚Ñùn√ón2assignŒîsuperscript~ùëùùëôùëötensor-productŒîsuperscriptsuperscriptùëùùëôùëötopsubscriptùêºùëõsuperscript‚Ñùùëõsuperscriptùëõ2\Delta\tilde{p}^{l,m}:=\Delta(p^{l,m})^{\top}\otimes I_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n% \times n^{2}}roman_Œî over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l , italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_Œî ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l , italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚äó italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n √ó italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ‚äótensor-product\otimes‚äó indicates the Kronecker product. The measurement noise is described by vk‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0n,Rk)similar-tosuperscriptùë£ùëòùí©subscript0ùëõsuperscriptùëÖùëòv^{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0_{n},R^{k})italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where RksuperscriptùëÖùëòR^{k}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is its corresponding covariance matrix. This noise accounts for the contribution of the external influence dùëëditalic_d to the change of opinions Œî‚Å¢xŒîùë•\Delta xroman_Œî italic_x.

Remark 3.5.

The measurement model (11) is obtained from a first-order Taylor approximation of the steady-state map around pk‚àí1superscriptùëùùëò1p^{k-1}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., h‚Å¢(pk,d)‚âàh‚Å¢(pk‚àí1,d)+‚àáph‚Å¢(pk‚àí1,d)‚ä§‚Å¢(pk‚àípk‚àí1)‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëòùëë‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëò1ùëësubscript‚àáùëù‚Ñésuperscriptsuperscriptùëùùëò1ùëëtopsuperscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptùëùùëò1h(p^{k},d)\approx h(p^{k-1},d)+\nabla_{p}h(p^{k-1},d)^{\top}(p^{k}-p^{k-1})italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) ‚âà italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) + ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). With this intuition, it can be seen that the measurement model is a linear time-variant approximation of the temporal evolution of the sensitivity ‚àáph‚Å¢(pk,d)subscript‚àáùëù‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëòùëë\nabla_{p}h(p^{k},d)‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ). Note that, the steady-state h‚Å¢(pk,d)‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëòùëëh(p^{k},d)italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) is reached only asymptotically. Thus, it is common practice [19] to use instead Œî‚Å¢xs‚Å¢sk+1,k=xk+1‚àíxkŒîsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëò1ùëòùë†ùë†superscriptùë•ùëò1superscriptùë•ùëò\Delta x^{k+1,k}_{ss}=x^{k+1}-x^{k}roman_Œî italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the measurement in (11). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square‚ñ°

The posterior update of sensitivity estimates ‚Ñì^ksuperscript^‚Ñìùëò\hat{\ell}^{k}over^ start_ARG roman_‚Ñì end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and covariance Œ£ksuperscriptŒ£ùëò\Sigma^{k}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are given by

‚Ñì^ksuperscript^‚Ñìùëò\displaystyle\hat{\ell}^{k}over^ start_ARG roman_‚Ñì end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =‚Ñì^k‚àí1+Œ∂k‚Å¢Kk‚àí1‚Å¢(Œî‚Å¢x^k+1,œÑi+1‚àíŒî‚Å¢p~k,œÑi‚Å¢‚Ñì^k‚àí1)absentsuperscript^‚Ñìùëò1superscriptùúÅùëòsuperscriptùêæùëò1Œîsuperscript^ùë•ùëò1subscriptùúèùëñ1Œîsuperscript~ùëùùëòsubscriptùúèùëñsuperscript^‚Ñìùëò1\displaystyle=\hat{\ell}^{k-1}+\zeta^{k}K^{k-1}\big{(}\Delta\hat{x}^{k+1,\tau_% {i}+1}-\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}}\hat{\ell}^{k-1}\big{)}= over^ start_ARG roman_‚Ñì end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Œî over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Œî over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG roman_‚Ñì end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
Œ£ksuperscriptŒ£ùëò\displaystyle\Sigma^{k}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =Œ£k‚àí1+Œ∂k‚Å¢(Qk‚àíKk‚àí1‚Å¢Œî‚Å¢p~k,œÑi‚Å¢Œ£k‚àí1),absentsuperscriptŒ£ùëò1superscriptùúÅùëòsuperscriptùëÑùëòsuperscriptùêæùëò1Œîsuperscript~ùëùùëòsubscriptùúèùëñsuperscriptŒ£ùëò1\displaystyle=\Sigma^{k-1}+\zeta^{k}\big{(}Q^{k}-K^{k-1}\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,% \tau_{i}}\Sigma^{k-1}\big{)},= roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œî over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (12)

where Œ∂ùúÅ\zetaitalic_Œ∂ enforces an auxiliary trigger mechanism, with

Œ∂k={1,k=i‚Å¢T0,otherwise.superscriptùúÅùëòcases1ùëòùëñùëá0otherwise\zeta^{k}=\Bigg{\{}\begin{array}[]{ll}1,&k=iT\\ 0,&\rm otherwise\end{array}.italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL 1 , end_CELL start_CELL italic_k = italic_i italic_T end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 , end_CELL start_CELL roman_otherwise end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY .

The trigger mechanism is introduced for the recommender system to update positions close to steady state, see Remark 1, and to collect a sufficient number of clicks to ensure a proper estimate of the CTR needed for opinion estimation. The trigger mechanism is turned on at integer multiples i‚àà‚Ñïùëñ‚Ñïi\in\mathbb{N}italic_i ‚àà blackboard_N of the time period TùëáTitalic_T. We define ùíØùíØ\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T as the set of all trigger time instances, with œÑi‚ààùíØsubscriptùúèùëñùíØ\tau_{i}\in\mathcal{T}italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_T representing the most recent trigger time instance prior to kùëòkitalic_k. Note that the update (3.2.1) uses the opinion estimate x^^ùë•\hat{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG introduced in ¬ß3.1.1 rather than the real users‚Äô opinion, with x^k+1=Œ≤^‚Å¢(yk,pk)superscript^ùë•ùëò1^ùõΩsuperscriptùë¶ùëòsuperscriptùëùùëò\hat{x}^{k+1}=\hat{\beta}(y^{k},p^{k})over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where yk:=‚àët=œÑikct/(k‚àíœÑi+1)assignsuperscriptùë¶ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë°subscriptùúèùëñùëòsuperscriptùëêùë°ùëòsubscriptùúèùëñ1y^{k}:=\sum_{t=\tau_{i}}^{k}c^{t}/(k-\tau_{i}+1)italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( italic_k - italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 ) is the CTR since the most recent trigger time instant. Finally, the Kalman filter gain KksuperscriptùêæùëòK^{k}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (3.2.1) is given by

Kk=Œ£k‚Å¢(Œî‚Å¢p~k,œÑi)‚ä§‚Å¢(Rk+Œî‚Å¢p~k,œÑi‚Å¢Œ£k‚Å¢(Œî‚Å¢p~k,œÑi)‚ä§)‚àí1,superscriptùêæùëòsuperscriptŒ£ùëòsuperscriptŒîsuperscript~ùëùùëòsubscriptùúèùëñtopsuperscriptsuperscriptùëÖùëòŒîsuperscript~ùëùùëòsubscriptùúèùëñsuperscriptŒ£ùëòsuperscriptŒîsuperscript~ùëùùëòsubscriptùúèùëñtop1K^{k}=\Sigma^{k}(\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}})^{\top}(R^{k}+\Delta\tilde{p}^{k% ,\tau_{i}}\Sigma^{k}(\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}})^{\top})^{-1},italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Œî over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œî over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Œî over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (13)

with Œî‚Å¢p~k,œÑiŒîsuperscript~ùëùùëòsubscriptùúèùëñ\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}}roman_Œî over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_œÑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and RksuperscriptùëÖùëòR^{k}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as in the measurement model (11). Next, we postulate some regularity assumptions for the process and measurement models.

Assumption 4 (Gaussian noise)

The process and measurement noise w,vùë§ùë£w,vitalic_w , italic_v are white Gaussian. Moreover, the steady-state opinion estimation error ex=h‚Å¢(p,d)‚àíŒ≤^‚Å¢(y,p)subscriptùëíùë•‚Ñéùëùùëë^ùõΩùë¶ùëùe_{x}=h(p,d)-\hat{\beta}(y,p)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) - over^ start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_p ) is uncorrelated with wùë§witalic_w and vùë£vitalic_v. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square‚ñ°

The assumption of white noise for the process model is standard in the context of sensitivity learning in feedback optimization [19]. Intuitively, the process perturbation determines the degree of trust one puts on the sensitivity estimates. It is also reasonable to assume that the external influence is uncorrelated among users in certain cases, for example the extended FJ model in (2) where d=x0ùëësubscriptùë•0d=x_{0}italic_d = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also note that since x^^ùë•\hat{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG is estimated using the ANN, the steady-state estimation error exsubscriptùëíùë•e_{x}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not correlated with the process or measurement noises in (10), (11). Under Assumption 4, the covariances simplify as Qk=(œÉqk)2‚Å¢In2superscriptùëÑùëòsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëûùëò2subscriptùêºsuperscriptùëõ2Q^{k}=(\sigma_{q}^{k})^{2}I_{n^{2}}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Rk=(œÉrk)2‚Å¢InsuperscriptùëÖùëòsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëüùëò2subscriptùêºùëõR^{k}=(\sigma_{r}^{k})^{2}I_{n}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for some œÉqsubscriptùúéùëû\sigma_{q}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, œÉr>0subscriptùúéùëü0\sigma_{r}>0italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0. The tuning of œÉq,œÉrsubscriptùúéùëûsubscriptùúéùëü\sigma_{q},\sigma_{r}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is based on heuristics and is described in Appendix¬†5.4.

To ensure that the sensitivity is correctly inferred, we must guarantee that the input positions Œî‚Å¢pŒîùëù\Delta proman_Œî italic_p are persistently exciting (see Definition 2). This translates to Œî‚Å¢pŒîùëù\Delta proman_Œî italic_p being sufficiently variable in order to explore the underlying user opinion dynamics. To do so, we work under the following assumption.

Assumption 5 (Persistency of excitation)

The inputs Œî‚Å¢pŒîùëù\Delta proman_Œî italic_p are persistently exciting (see Definition 2) and the trigger mechanism in (3.2.1) is activated at least S+1ùëÜ1S+1italic_S + 1 times, namely |ùíØ|‚â•S+1ùíØùëÜ1|\mathcal{T}|\geq S+1| caligraphic_T | ‚â• italic_S + 1. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\square‚ñ°

In practice, this assumption can be satisfied by introducing a dither signal in the update rule (6).

3.3 Level III: Gradient Estimation & Optimization

We describe the gradient estimation method for the engagement cost function in (3). We remark that this algorithmic step is needed as the clicking behaviour is unknown. We then describe the OFO update rule from (6), incorporating gradient, sensitivity and state estimation.

3.3.1 Gradient Estimation

To estimate the gradient of the engagement maximization cost œÜctrsuperscriptùúëctr\varphi^{\rm ctr}italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we use the finite forward difference method [42]

‚àáxœÜ^ictr‚Å¢(p,x)=œÜ^ctr‚Å¢(p,x+Œº‚Å¢ei)‚àíœÜ^ctr‚Å¢(p,x)Œº,subscript‚àáùë•subscriptsuperscript^ùúëctrùëñùëùùë•superscript^ùúëctrùëùùë•ùúásubscriptùëíùëñsuperscript^ùúëctrùëùùë•ùúá\nabla_{x}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}_{i}(p,x)=\frac{\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p,x+% \mu e_{i})-\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p,x)}{\mu},‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) = divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x + italic_Œº italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG , (14)
‚àápœÜ^ictr‚Å¢(p,x)=œÜ^ctr‚Å¢(p+Œº‚Å¢ei,x)‚àíœÜ^ctr‚Å¢(p,x)Œº,subscript‚àáùëùsubscriptsuperscript^ùúëctrùëñùëùùë•superscript^ùúëctrùëùùúásubscriptùëíùëñùë•superscript^ùúëctrùëùùë•ùúá\nabla_{p}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}_{i}(p,x)=\frac{\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p+\mu e% _{i},x)-\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p,x)}{\mu},‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) = divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p + italic_Œº italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ) - over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG , (15)

where ‚àájœÜ^ictr,j‚àà{p,x}subscript‚àáùëósubscriptsuperscript^ùúëctrùëñùëóùëùùë•\nabla_{j}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}_{i},j\in\{p,x\}‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j ‚àà { italic_p , italic_x } denotes the iùëñiitalic_i-th entry of the gradient, ei‚àà‚Ñùnsubscriptùëíùëñsuperscript‚Ñùùëõe_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT refers to the iùëñiitalic_i-th vector of the canonical basis of ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Œºùúá\muitalic_Œº is a smoothing parameter. Note that in the two-point gradient estimation, we do not actuate the opinion dynamics twice but rather use the engagement cost function estimate œÜ^ctr‚Å¢(p,x)=‚àí1n‚ä§‚Å¢g^‚Å¢(p,x)superscript^ùúëctrùëùùë•superscriptsubscript1ùëõtop^ùëîùëùùë•\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p,x)=-1_{n}^{\top}\hat{g}(p,x)over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) = - 1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , italic_x ) as described in ¬ß3.1.2.

The smoothing parameter Œºùúá\muitalic_Œº is chosen small enough so that the gradient estimate provides a good approximation of the true value. However, choosing Œºùúá\muitalic_Œº in (14)‚Äì(15) too small can lead to numerical instability, as formalized in the following.

Lemma 3.6 (Gradient estimation error).

Under Assumptions 2‚Äì3, the gradient estimation error is upper bounded as

‚à•‚àájœÜ^ctr‚àí‚àájœÜctr‚à•‚â§12‚Å¢Lx‚Å¢Œº+2‚Å¢n‚Å¢œµgŒº,j‚àà{x,p}.formulae-sequencedelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript‚àáùëósuperscript^ùúëctrsubscript‚àáùëósuperscriptùúëctr12subscriptùêøùë•ùúá2ùëõsubscriptitalic-œµùëîùúáùëóùë•ùëù\lVert\nabla_{j}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}-\nabla_{j}\varphi^{\rm ctr}\rVert\leq% \frac{1}{2}L_{x}\mu+2\frac{\sqrt{n}\epsilon_{g}}{\mu},\quad j\in\{x,p\}.‚à• ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº + 2 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG , italic_j ‚àà { italic_x , italic_p } .

The upper bound attains its lowest value 2‚Å¢n3/4‚Å¢œµg‚Å¢Lj2superscriptùëõ34subscriptitalic-œµùëîsubscriptùêøùëó2n^{3/4}\sqrt{\epsilon_{g}L_{j}}2 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG at Œº‚àó=2‚Å¢n1/4‚Å¢œµg/Ljsuperscriptùúá2superscriptùëõ14subscriptitalic-œµùëîsubscriptùêøùëó\mu^{*}=2n^{1/4}\sqrt{{\epsilon_{g}}/{L_{j}}}italic_Œº start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, with j‚àà{x,p}ùëóùë•ùëùj\in\{x,p\}italic_j ‚àà { italic_x , italic_p }.

Proof 3.7.

Refer to Appendix 5.5.

3.3.2 Projected Gradient Descent Algorithm

We now present the projected-gradient update in (6) augmented with sensitivity, state, and gradient estimations. The augmented update reads compactly as

pk+1=Œ†[‚àí1,1]n‚Å¢[pk‚àíŒ∂k‚Å¢Œ∑‚Å¢Œ¶^k],superscriptùëùùëò1subscriptŒ†superscript11ùëõdelimited-[]superscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptùúÅùëòùúÇsuperscript^Œ¶ùëòp^{k+1}=\Pi_{[-1,1]^{n}}\Big{[}p^{k}-\zeta^{k}\eta\,\hat{\Phi}^{k}\Big{]},italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Œ† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ over^ start_ARG roman_Œ¶ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , (16)

where the gradient surrogate Œ¶^^Œ¶\hat{\Phi}over^ start_ARG roman_Œ¶ end_ARG is constructed by combining sensitivity, opinion, and gradient estimates as

Œ¶^k=superscript^Œ¶ùëòabsent\displaystyle\hat{\Phi}^{k}=over^ start_ARG roman_Œ¶ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ‚àápœÜ^ctr‚Å¢(pk,x^k+1)+(H^k)‚ä§‚Å¢‚àáxœÜ^ctr‚Å¢(pk,x^k+1)subscript‚àáùëùsuperscript^ùúëctrsuperscriptùëùùëòsuperscript^ùë•ùëò1superscriptsuperscript^ùêªùëòtopsubscript‚àáùë•superscript^ùúëctrsuperscriptùëùùëòsuperscript^ùë•ùëò1\displaystyle\nabla_{p}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p^{k},\hat{x}^{k+1})+(\hat{H}^{% k})^{\top}\nabla_{x}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p^{k},\hat{x}^{k+1})‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_œÜ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
+Œ≥‚Å¢(H^k)‚ä§‚Å¢‚àáxœÜpol‚Å¢(x^k+1)‚àíwpek/Œ∑,ùõæsuperscriptsuperscript^ùêªùëòtopsubscript‚àáùë•superscriptùúëpolsuperscript^ùë•ùëò1superscriptsubscriptùë§peùëòùúÇ\displaystyle+\gamma(\hat{H}^{k})^{\top}\nabla_{x}\varphi^{\rm pol}(\hat{x}^{k% +1})-w_{\rm pe}^{k}/\eta,+ italic_Œ≥ ( over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Œ∑ , (17)

where H^k:=‚àáph^‚Å¢(pk,d)assignsuperscript^ùêªùëòsubscript‚àáùëù^‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëòùëë\hat{H}^{k}:=\nabla_{p}\hat{h}(p^{k},d)over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) is the sensitivity estimate at time kùëòkitalic_k. The additional term wpek‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0n,œÉpe2‚Å¢In)similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptùë§peùëòùí©subscript0ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùúépe2subscriptùêºùëõw_{\rm pe}^{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0_{n},\sigma_{\rm pe}^{2}I_{n})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a dither signal that ensures persistency of excitation of the inputs (Assumption 5).

In Algorithm 1, we summarize the pseudo-code of the proposed recommender system design. In the offline phase, training of the neural network is carried out for opinion and clicking behaviour estimation. In the online phase, a new sensitivity estimate is generated and new positions are provided to the users periodically, every TùëáTitalic_T time steps.

3.4 Closed-loop Convergence Guarantees

Here, we establish convergence guarantees for the sensitivity estimation process (3.2.1) and for the closed-loop interconnection between the opinions and recommendations. Before stating the formal results, we make some important observations regarding our opinion estimation technique and its implication on the closed-loop convergence analysis.

In our problem setup, the measurement information at each time instant (i.e., a single click/no click data), is not rich enough to produce accurate estimates for the users‚Äô real-time opinion. As shown in Algorithm¬†1, the opinion estimation is instead carried out using the CTR recorded on multiple recommendations with a constant position since the previous trigger instant. In light of the exponential stability of the opinion dynamics (i.e., Assumption 1), the resulting estimate at the end of each trigger period is, in practice, close to an estimate of the steady-state opinion h‚Å¢(pk,d)‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëòùëëh(p^{k},d)italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ). This approach is therefore substantially different from real-time state estimation [21]. Thus, as we directly estimate steady-state opinions at each trigger instant, we can greatly simplify our closed-loop stability analysis by treating the opinion dynamics as a static mapping. Also note that as the trigger period TùëáTitalic_T increases, the resulting CTR offers a better approximation of the CTR in expectation ùîº‚Å¢[g‚Å¢(p,x)]ùîºdelimited-[]ùëîùëùùë•\mathbb{E}\big{[}g(p,x)\big{]}blackboard_E [ italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) ]. The modeling errors Œ∏x,Œ±ysubscriptùúÉùë•subscriptùõºùë¶\theta_{x},\alpha_{y}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Lemma¬†2,¬†3.2 exist due to a finite time horizon TùëáTitalic_T and reduces as TùëáTitalic_T increases.

Now, we state the main convergence result with respect to the sensitivity estimation error.

Theorem 3.8 (Sensitivity estimate convergence).

Under Assumptions 1, 4, and 5, the sensitivity estimation error ek:=‚Ñìk‚àí‚Ñì^kassignsuperscriptùëíùëòsuperscript‚Ñìùëòsuperscript^‚Ñìùëòe^{k}:=\ell^{k}-\hat{\ell}^{k}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG roman_‚Ñì end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has bias and variance bounded in norm, i.e., there exist positive constants c1,c2,Cf<‚àûsubscriptùëê1subscriptùëê2subscriptùê∂ùëìc_{1},c_{2},C_{f}<\inftyitalic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ‚àû and Œæ‚àà(0,1)ùúâ01\xi\in(0,1)italic_Œæ ‚àà ( 0 , 1 ) such that

‚à•ùîº‚Å¢[ek]‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùëíùëò\displaystyle\lVert\mathbb{E}[e^{k}]\rVert‚à• blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ‚à• ‚â§2‚Å¢Km‚Å¢œµx/(1‚àíc1‚Å¢Œæc2‚Å¢T)+(c1‚Å¢Œæc2‚Å¢T)|ùíØ|‚Å¢‚à•ùîº‚Å¢[e0]‚à•absent2subscriptùêæùëösubscriptitalic-œµùë•1subscriptùëê1superscriptùúâsubscriptùëê2ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëê1superscriptùúâsubscriptùëê2ùëáùíØdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùëí0\displaystyle\leq 2K_{m}\epsilon_{x}/(1-c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T})+(c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T})% ^{|\mathcal{T}|}\lVert\mathbb{E}[e^{0}]\rVert‚â§ 2 italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_T | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ‚à•
ùîº‚Å¢[‚à•ek‚à•2]ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùëíùëò2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\Big{[}\lVert e^{k}\rVert^{2}\Big{]}blackboard_E [ ‚à• italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ‚â§Cf+(c1‚Å¢Œæc2‚Å¢T)2‚Å¢|ùíØ|‚Å¢ùîº‚Å¢[‚à•e0‚à•2]absentsubscriptùê∂ùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1superscriptùúâsubscriptùëê2ùëá2ùíØùîºdelimited-[]superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùëí02\displaystyle\leq C_{f}+(c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T})^{2|\mathcal{T}|}\mathbb{E}\Big{[}% \lVert e^{0}\rVert^{2}\Big{]}‚â§ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 | caligraphic_T | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ ‚à• italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]

end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à•, c1‚Å¢Œæc2‚Å¢T<1subscriptùëê1superscriptùúâsubscriptùëê2ùëá1c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T}<1italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 1.

Proof 3.9.

Refer to Appendix 5.6.

Note that both bias and variance upper bounds depend on the opinion estimation error œµxsubscriptitalic-œµùë•\epsilon_{x}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Further, note that increasing the sampling period TùëáTitalic_T reduces the bias and variance error through the term 1‚àíc1‚Å¢Œæc2‚Å¢T1subscriptùëê1superscriptùúâsubscriptùëê2ùëá1-c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T}1 - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is expected as increasing TùëáTitalic_T guarantees greater time-scale separation between opinion dynamics and recommendations. Finally, the upper bound on the sensitivity error variance is proportional to the noise variance of the opinions through the term œÉ¬Ør2superscriptsubscript¬Øùúéùëü2\overline{\sigma}_{r}^{2}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

To quantify performance on the recommendations, we use the fixed-point residual mapping [43, Eq. (5)]

ùí¢‚Å¢(p):=1Œ∑‚Å¢(p‚àíŒ†[‚àí1,1]n‚Å¢[p‚àíŒ∑‚Å¢Œ¶‚Å¢(p,h‚Å¢(p,d))]).assignùí¢ùëù1ùúÇùëùsubscriptŒ†superscript11ùëõdelimited-[]ùëùùúÇŒ¶ùëù‚Ñéùëùùëë\mathcal{G}(p):=\frac{1}{\eta}\Big{(}p-\Pi_{[-1,1]^{n}}\big{[}p-\eta\Phi(p,h(p% ,d))\big{]}\Big{)}.caligraphic_G ( italic_p ) := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG ( italic_p - roman_Œ† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p - italic_Œ∑ roman_Œ¶ ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) ] ) . (18)

The fixed-point residual mapping is zero at any critical point of (5), and is a common metric to quantify convergence of iterative algorithms in non-convex regimes [26].

The following theorem shows the convergence of the closed-loop system, combining Levels I, II, and III in Figure 2, using the second moment of the fixed-point residual mapping. Since the problem is non-convex, the trajectories of {pk}k=0Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëòùëò0ùëÅ\{p^{k}\}_{k=0}^{N}{ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT vary across each trial. Thus, it is essential to evaluate ‚à•ùí¢‚Å¢(pk)‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùí¢superscriptùëùùëò\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{k})\rVert‚à• caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à• with its expectation. Moreover, we compute the average of this metric over all the trigger time instances to reflect the average performance of Algorithm¬†1 over the time in which recommendations are provided. The theoretical bound is only computed over the trigger time instances since the positions remain constant between two trigger instances, and so does the residual ‚à•ùí¢‚Å¢(pk)‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùí¢superscriptùëùùëò\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{k})\rVert‚à• caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à•.

Theorem 3.10 (Closed-loop convergence).

Let Assumptions 1‚Äì5 hold. For any Œ∑‚àà(0,12‚Å¢L‚Ä≤)ùúÇ012superscriptùêø‚Ä≤\eta\in(0,\frac{1}{2L^{\prime}})italic_Œ∑ ‚àà ( 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) and Œº‚àó=2‚Å¢n1/4‚Å¢œµg/Lj,j‚àà{p,x}formulae-sequencesuperscriptùúá2superscriptùëõ14subscriptitalic-œµùëîsubscriptùêøùëóùëóùëùùë•\mu^{*}=2n^{1/4}\sqrt{{\epsilon_{g}}/{L_{j}}},j\in\{p,x\}italic_Œº start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_j ‚àà { italic_p , italic_x }, the sequence {pk}k‚àà‚Ñïsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëòùëò‚Ñï\{p^{k}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ‚àà blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated by (16) satisfies

Proof 3.11.

Refer to Appendix 5.15.

Note that an upper bound on the minimum of ‚à•ùí¢‚Å¢(pk)‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùí¢superscriptùëùùëò\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{k})\rVert‚à• caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à• can be inferred from (19), through the inequality ùîº‚Å¢[minl‚ààùíØ‚Å¢‚à•ùí¢‚Å¢(pl)‚à•2]‚â§ùîº‚Å¢[1|ùíØ|‚Å¢‚àël‚ààùíØ‚à•ùí¢‚Å¢(pl)‚à•2]=1|ùíØ|‚Å¢ùîº‚Å¢[‚àël‚ààùíØ‚à•ùí¢‚Å¢(pl)‚à•2]ùîºdelimited-[]ùëôùíØminsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùí¢superscriptùëùùëô2ùîºdelimited-[]1ùíØsubscriptùëôùíØsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùí¢superscriptùëùùëô21ùíØùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëôùíØsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùí¢superscriptùëùùëô2\mathbb{E}\Big{[}\underset{l\in\mathcal{T}}{\mathrm{min}}\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{% l})\rVert^{2}\Big{]}\leq\mathbb{E}\Big{[}\frac{1}{|\mathcal{T}|}\sum_{l\in% \mathcal{T}}\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{l})\rVert^{2}\Big{]}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{T}|}% \mathbb{E}\Big{[}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{T}}\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{l})\rVert^{2}\Big{]}blackboard_E [ start_UNDERACCENT italic_l ‚àà caligraphic_T end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_min end_ARG ‚à• caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ‚â§ blackboard_E [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_T | end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ‚àà caligraphic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_T | end_ARG blackboard_E [ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ‚àà caligraphic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], see [23, Remark 5]. Thus, intuitively, the bound in (19) describes the maximum possible minimum gap between the trajectory {pk,h‚Å¢(pk,d)}k=0Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëò‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëòùëëùëò0ùëÅ\{p^{k},h(p^{k},d)\}_{k=0}^{N}{ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained using Algorithm 1 and a local minima (p‚àó,h‚Å¢(p‚àó,d))superscriptùëù‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëë(p^{*},h(p^{*},d))( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) ).

The bound K1subscriptùêæ1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT shows that achieving an accurate solution of (5), i.e., a local minima (p‚àó,h‚Å¢(p‚àó,d))superscriptùëù‚Ñésuperscriptùëùùëë(p^{*},h(p^{*},d))( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) ), is limited by the deviation of the initial cost at (p0,h‚Å¢(p0,d))superscriptùëù0‚Ñésuperscriptùëù0ùëë(p^{0},h(p^{0},d))( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) ) from the optimal one œÜ‚àósuperscriptùúë\varphi^{*}italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., the term Œ∫1subscriptùúÖ1\kappa_{1}italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), the polarization and engagement gradient estimation errors (i.e., the terms Œ∫2,Œ∫3subscriptùúÖ2subscriptùúÖ3\kappa_{2},\kappa_{3}italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively) including both opinion and clicking behaviour estimation errors, the variance of the dither signal œÉpe2superscriptsubscriptùúépe2\sigma_{\rm pe}^{2}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the sensitivity estimation error variance ùîº‚Å¢[‚à•el‚à•2]ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùëíùëô2\mathbb{E}[\lVert e^{l}\rVert^{2}]blackboard_E [ ‚à• italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ].

Corollary 3.12 (Asymptotic convergence).

As |ùíØ|‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùíØ|\mathcal{T}|\rightarrow\infty| caligraphic_T | ‚Üí ‚àû, the upper bound K1subscriptùêæ1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in in Theorem 3.10 approaches K2subscriptùêæ2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, given by

K2=61‚àí2‚Å¢Œ∑‚Å¢L‚Ä≤(\displaystyle K_{2}=\frac{6}{1-2\eta L^{\prime}}\Bigg{(}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 6 end_ARG start_ARG 1 - 2 italic_Œ∑ italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( 2‚Å¢Cf‚Å¢(2‚Å¢n‚Å¢Œ≥2+Mx2+4‚Å¢n3/2‚Å¢œµg‚Å¢Lx)+limit-from2subscriptùê∂ùëì2ùëõsuperscriptùõæ2superscriptsubscriptùëÄùë•24superscriptùëõ32subscriptitalic-œµùëîsubscriptùêøùë•\displaystyle 2C_{f}(2n\gamma^{2}+M_{x}^{2}+4n^{3/2}\epsilon_{g}L_{x})+2 italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2 italic_n italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 4 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) +
4(Œ∫2+Œ∫3)+œÉpe2Œ∑2)\displaystyle 4(\kappa_{2}+\kappa_{3})+\frac{\sigma_{\rm pe}^{2}}{\eta^{2}}% \Bigg{)}4 ( italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG )
Proof 3.13.

Refer to Appendix 5.15.

From K2subscriptùêæ2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we observe that the asymptotic accuracy is limited by a combination of gradient estimation errors, which include opinion and clicking behaviour estimation (i.e., the terms Œ∫2,Œ∫3subscriptùúÖ2subscriptùúÖ3\kappa_{2},\kappa_{3}italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), the sensitivity estimation error, and the variance of the dither signal œÉpe2superscriptsubscriptùúépe2\sigma_{\rm pe}^{2}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, the upper-bound of the average of the variance of sensitivity estimation error over the trigger time instances approaches Cfsubscriptùê∂ùëìC_{f}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the asymptotic sensitivity error variance.

4 Numerical Case Studies

4.1 Opinion Dynamics and Clicking Behaviour

We assume the opinions of the users on the platform evolve according to the FJ model as in Example 1, i.e.,

xk+1=(In‚àíŒìp‚àíŒìd)‚Å¢A‚Å¢xk+Œìp‚Å¢pk+Œìd‚Å¢d.superscriptùë•ùëò1subscriptùêºùëõsubscriptŒìùëùsubscriptŒìùëëùê¥superscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptŒìùëùsuperscriptùëùùëòsubscriptŒìùëëùëëx^{k+1}=(I_{n}-\Gamma_{p}-\Gamma_{d})Ax^{k}+\Gamma_{p}p^{k}+\Gamma_{d}d.italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_A italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d .

Further, we consider users with two different clicking behaviours: confirmation bias towards extreme positions, CAsubscriptùê∂ùê¥C_{A}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined as in Example 2, and confirmation bias towards any position, CBsubscriptùê∂ùêµC_{B}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, wherein the click event is given by

ci‚àº‚Ñ¨‚Å¢(12+12‚Å¢e‚àí4‚Å¢(xi‚àípi)2).similar-tosubscriptùëêùëñ‚Ñ¨1212superscriptùëí4superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ2c_{i}\sim\mathcal{B}\Big{(}\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}e^{-4(x_{i}-p_{i})^{2}}\Big{% )}.italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_B ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (20)

Note that the choice of these clicking behaviors make the steady-state optimization problem (5) non-convex.

As a proof of concept, we consider a platform with n=15ùëõ15n=15italic_n = 15 users. We generate the adjacency matrix Aùê¥Aitalic_A with some random entries zero and other entries sampled from ùí∞‚Å¢[0,1]ùí∞01\mathcal{U}[0,1]caligraphic_U [ 0 , 1 ]222This ensures that the non-zero weights in the graph are not insignificant. such that A‚Å¢ùüèn‚â§ùüènùê¥subscript1ùëõsubscript1ùëõA\mathbf{1}_{n}\leq\mathbf{1}_{n}italic_A bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, the resulting graph need not be strongly connected. We generate the initial opinions as x0‚àºùí∞‚Å¢[‚àí1,1]nsimilar-tosuperscriptùë•0ùí∞superscript11ùëõx^{0}\sim\mathcal{U}[-1,1]^{n}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_U [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, we set Œìd=0.5‚Å¢diag‚Å¢[|x0|]subscriptŒìùëë0.5diagdelimited-[]superscriptùë•0\Gamma_{d}=0.5\mathrm{diag}[|x^{0}|]roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5 roman_diag [ | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ]. This choice of ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indicates that the users who hold initial extreme opinions tend to be more stubborn. The external influence dùëëditalic_d is modelled as a prejudice term defined as the initial opinion x0superscriptùë•0x^{0}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, ŒìpsubscriptŒìùëù\Gamma_{p}roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn from ùíü[10‚àí2,0.5]nsuperscriptsubscriptùíüsuperscript1020.5ùëõ\mathcal{D}_{[10^{-2},0.5]}^{n}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0.5 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT so that all users are affected by the recommendations. To incorporate diversity in clicking behaviours, we randomly assign 8888 users to follow clicking behaviour CAsubscriptùê∂ùê¥C_{A}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the remaining ones follow CBsubscriptùê∂ùêµC_{B}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

4.2 Experimental Setting and Hyperparameter Selection

In the offline phase (Algorithm 2 in Appendix 5.1), we train the neural network for opinion and clicking behaviour estimation with m=375ùëö375m=375italic_m = 375 training and 125125125125 testing points, simulation time N=100ùëÅ100N=100italic_N = 100 and trigger period T=60ùëá60T=60italic_T = 60, with the clicks being recorded in the duration k‚àà[N‚àíT,N]ùëòùëÅùëáùëÅk\in[N-T,N]italic_k ‚àà [ italic_N - italic_T , italic_N ]. We set the trade-off factor Œ≥=1ùõæ1\gamma=1italic_Œ≥ = 1 in (3), thus giving equal importance to engagement maximization and polarization mitigation.

In the online phase, we choose œÉpe=0.07subscriptùúépe0.07\sigma_{\text{pe}}=0.07italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.07 in (16) for the first N/5ùëÅ5N/5italic_N / 5 time steps to facilitate sensitivity estimation333Sensitivity estimation can be halted after convergence on its entries. and network learning, and œÉpe=0subscriptùúépe0\sigma_{\text{pe}}=0italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 afterwards to favor accurate recommendations. In the Kalman filter (3.2.1), we initialize ‚Ñì^0=0.5‚Å¢vec‚Å¢(In)superscript^‚Ñì00.5vecsubscriptùêºùëõ\hat{\ell}^{0}=0.5{\rm vec}(I_{n})over^ start_ARG roman_‚Ñì end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.5 roman_vec ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Œ£0=In2superscriptŒ£0subscriptùêºsuperscriptùëõ2\Sigma^{0}=I_{n^{2}}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For gradient estimation in (14)‚Äì(15), we set the smoothing parameter Œº=0.1ùúá0.1\mu=0.1italic_Œº = 0.1. While tuning the process noise standard deviation, we set the tuning parameter MùëÄMitalic_M in (21) as M=10ùëÄ10M=10italic_M = 10. Further, we start with neutral recommendations, i.e., p0=0nsuperscriptùëù0subscript0ùëõp^{0}=0_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and consider a periodic trigger with period T=60ùëá60T=60italic_T = 60. For the polarization cost œÜpolsuperscriptùúëpol\varphi^{\rm pol}italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (4), we set œµ1=‚àí0.5subscriptitalic-œµ10.5\epsilon_{1}=-0.5italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - 0.5 and œµ2=0.5subscriptitalic-œµ20.5\epsilon_{2}=0.5italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5. All the simulations are conducted for N=2.5‚ãÖ104ùëÅ‚ãÖ2.5superscript104N=2.5\cdot 10^{4}italic_N = 2.5 ‚ãÖ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT time instances and over 50505050 Monte-Carlo trials. Since clicks are stochastic, the sequence of clicks varies across each trial. Moreover, the dither signal wpesubscriptùë§pew_{\rm pe}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sequence varies across each trial, thus leading to different sensitivity estimates.

4.3 Architecture Comparisons

In this section, we compare Algorithm 1 against other similar OFO approaches that benefit from more information.

In Table 2, we summarize all the methods used for comparison and their attributes. In particular, for the oracle (method M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), we employ the standard projected-gradient controller (6), wherein opinions can be directly measured, and the sensitivity and users‚Äô clicking behavior are both known.

Method M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uses online sensitivity estimation. Method M3subscriptùëÄ3M_{3}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uses opinion as well as sensitivity estimation. Finally, method M4subscriptùëÄ4M_{4}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT corresponds to Algorithm 1, and includes also clicking behaviour and gradient estimation. All the methods‚Äô architecture can be extracted from Figure 2 by replacing or removing some of the blocks. Method M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would not require the ANN in Level-1, the Kalman filter in Level-2 and gradient estimation in Level-3. Method M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would not require the ANN and gradient estimation. Method M3subscriptùëÄ3M_{3}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would need the ANN only for opinion estimation, but does not require gradient estimation.

Figure 3 shows that convergence is empirically established in all the methods through the fixed-point residual mapping norm ‚à•ùí¢‚Å¢(pk)‚à•2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùí¢superscriptùëùùëò2\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{k})\rVert^{2}‚à• caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, for methods that involve sensitivity estimation (i.e., M2‚àíM4subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ4M_{2}-M_{4}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), we observe a higher fluctuation for the first N/5ùëÅ5N/5italic_N / 5 time instances due to the effect of the dither signal œÉpesubscriptùúépe\sigma_{\text{pe}}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our proposed method offers slightly inferior performances compared to the others, which is unsurprising as it is completely data-driven.

In Figure 4, we illustrate the relative sensitivity estimation error. It is expected that method M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT performs better than M3,M4subscriptùëÄ3subscriptùëÄ4M_{3},M_{4}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the opinions are known in real time. However, the methods that involve steady-state opinion estimation, M3,M4subscriptùëÄ3subscriptùëÄ4M_{3},M_{4}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, still show comparable performance. This is due to accurate opinion estimation, as can be seen from Figure 5, where we show the opinion estimates for four randomly chosen users, along with their true values. Finally, Figure 6, shows the effect of Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ in (3) on the trade-off between engagement maximization and polarization mitigation. As expected, increasing Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥, turns into a polarization cost reduction. However, the loss in engagement is not significant. This is due to the fact that roughly half of the agents follow clicking behaviour CBsubscriptùê∂ùêµC_{B}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and hence still get engaged by the non-extreme content that promotes polarization mitigation. A more significant engagement loss would be expected if all the users were to be engaged by extreme content only [9].

4.4 Impact of Network-aware Recommendations

In this case study, we showcase the impact of providing network-aware recommendations compared to individual, decoupled recommendations. To achieve this, we compare our approach with two network-agnostic methods: (i) the recommender system described in [9], and (ii) a naive version of our OFO-based recommender design.

The design in [9] provides recommendations with exclusively extreme positions (i.e., pi=¬±1subscriptùëùùëñplus-or-minus1p_{i}=\pm 1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ¬± 1) to each user independently. The position is calculated based on the user‚Äôs individual clicking history. Specifically, if a user more frequently clicks on +11+1+ 1 (or ‚àí11-1- 1) positions, the system will provide +11+1+ 1 (or ‚àí11-1- 1) positions with high probability. Conversely, if the user shows an equal likelihood of clicking on both +11+1+ 1 and ‚àí11-1- 1 positions, the recommendations will be random. It‚Äôs important to note that the comparison with the method in [9] is not entirely equitable in terms of methodology: their approach relies solely on extreme positions and does not target polarization reduction as an objective. However, we include this comparison because, to the best of our knowledge, it is the only model-free, opinion agnostic, systems-theory-based recommender design available.

The second method considered for comparison is a network-agnostic version of our recommender system design summarized in Algorithm 1. We will refer to this method as naive OFO. Specifically, for each user i‚àà[n]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëõi\in[n]italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ], we use a local ANN for opinion estimation that is trained using local positions and acceptance ratio, i.e., x^i=Œ≤^i‚Å¢(yi,pi)subscript^ùë•ùëñsubscript^ùõΩùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\hat{x}_{i}=\hat{\beta}_{i}(y_{i},p_{i})over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) rather than Œ≤^i‚Å¢(yi,p)subscript^ùõΩùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñùëù\hat{\beta}_{i}(y_{i},p)over^ start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p ). Further, we do not carry out sensitivity estimation and instead use a constant diagonal sensitivity H^‚ààùíü(0,0.5]n^ùêªsuperscriptsubscriptùíü00.5ùëõ\hat{H}\in\mathcal{D}_{(0,0.5]}^{n}over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ‚àà caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 , 0.5 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (17). The rationale behind this design choice is that if the network did not contribute to engagement maximization and/or polarization mitigation, a diagonal H^^ùêª\hat{H}over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG would yield the same performance as our network-aware approach.

We compare the performance of our recommender system with the other decoupled methods in terms of final mean CTR J:=‚àëk=N‚àíT+1N‚à•ck‚à•1/(n‚Å¢T)assignùêΩsuperscriptsubscriptùëòùëÅùëá1ùëÅsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùëêùëò1ùëõùëáJ:=\sum_{k=N-T+1}^{N}\lVert c^{k}\rVert_{1}/(nT)italic_J := ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = italic_N - italic_T + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_n italic_T ) and final polarization cost œÜpol‚Å¢(xN)superscriptùúëpolsuperscriptùë•ùëÅ\varphi^{\rm pol}(x^{N})italic_œÜ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in Figure 7 and the fixed point residual mapping in Figure 8. In Figure 7, we observe that our proposed algorithm achieves a slightly higher (‚àº1.3%similar-toabsentpercent1.3\sim 1.3\%‚àº 1.3 %) user engagement compared to its naive implementation and results in a lower polarization cost (‚àº9.3%similar-toabsentpercent9.3\sim 9.3\%‚àº 9.3 %). Thus, network-aware recommendations effectively reduce polarization while maintaining high user engagement. This performance improvement is further illustrated in Figure 8, which depicts the temporal evolution of the fixed-point residuals. This result is unsurprising since polarization is a global network metric, whereas engagement maximization can be addressed individually by tailoring recommended content for each user.

Note that the recommender design in [9] employs only extreme recommendations, naturally leading to higher polarization costs, as shown in Figure 7(b). Furthermore, it results in lower user engagement compared to both our algorithm and the naive method. This is because some users in the network are assigned clicking behavior CBsubscriptùê∂ùêµC_{B}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for which extreme recommendations do not necessarily increase engagement.

5 Conclusion

We introduced a novel recommender system algorithm based on online feedback optimization that balances the trade-off between maximizing user engagement (CTR) and minimizing polarization. By integrating auxiliary estimation blocks, our approach overcomes the limitations of existing OFO designs, which require unavailable real-time data, and instead relies solely on click data. We established theoretical guarantees for closed-loop stability and validated our design through numerical simulations using an extended FJ model. Our results demonstrated the impact of network-awareness in reducing polarization while maintaining high engagement.

Future compelling research directions include relaxing the smoothness assumptions for clicking behavior and exploring alternative interest drivers, such as repulsion, beyond confirmation bias. Parameter estimation for clicking behavior could also be refined by using a grey-box model instead of a purely black-box approach. Additionally, investigating the impact of different graph topologies on polarization and developing distributed algorithms for more efficient sensitivity estimation in large-scale networks would be valuable. Lastly, we hope our network-centered approach contributes to the literature on mitigating opinion polarization through algorithmic systems.

Appendix

5.1 Training Data

The training of the neural network is carried out offline via feed-forward and back-propagation [44]. Algorithm 2, provides the pseudo-code to acquire the training data.

For each training sample k‚àà[m]ùëòdelimited-[]ùëök\in[m]italic_k ‚àà [ italic_m ], we provide news expressing a fixed random position p¬Ø¬Øùëù\overline{p}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_p end_ARG to the users for a period of NùëÅNitalic_N time steps. The term TùëáTitalic_T is a design parameter, with (N‚àíT)ùëÅùëá(N-T)( italic_N - italic_T ) representing a time instant at which opinions have reached a steady-state. After NùëÅNitalic_N steps, we obtain the users‚Äô rating xNsuperscriptùë•ùëÅx^{N}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and compute their CTR for the position p¬Ø¬Øùëù\overline{p}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_p end_ARG based on the last TùëáTitalic_T time steps. This process is carried out over mùëömitalic_m Monte Carlo trials, thus collecting mùëömitalic_m training data points. We emphasize that, similarly to what happens in real life with recommender systems asking the users to rate their experiences, for each trial, we only require access to one sample from the user opinion dynamics, xNsuperscriptùë•ùëÅx^{N}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The real time opinions in each trial {xk}k=0N‚àí1superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëòùëò0ùëÅ1\{x^{k}\}_{k=0}^{N-1}{ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are not needed.

5.2 Proof of Lemma 2

The proof follows from [45, Corollary 5.2] with the continuous function Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤ playing the same role as fùëìfitalic_f in [45].

In order to provide an explicit upper-bound for exsubscriptùëíùë•e_{x}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we point out that the neural network makes use of three layers: the injection layer, whose map is represented by u:‚Ñùn+1‚Üí‚Ñùn+2:ùë¢‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ1superscript‚Ñùùëõ2u:\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\to\mathbb{R}^{n+2}italic_u : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the intermediate layer whose map is represented by z:‚Ñùn+2‚Üí‚Ñùn+2:ùëß‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ2superscript‚Ñùùëõ2z:\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\to\mathbb{R}^{n+2}italic_z : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the output layer, whose map is represented by v:‚Ñùn+2‚Üí‚Ñù:ùë£‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëõ2‚Ñùv:\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\to\mathbb{R}italic_v : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R, with v‚Å¢(z)=v‚ä§‚Å¢z+v0ùë£ùëßsuperscriptùë£topùëßsubscriptùë£0v(z)=v^{\top}z+v_{0}italic_v ( italic_z ) = italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z + italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Given that the input and output layers are linear maps, we can directly make use of [46, Theorem 7] to state the following upper-bound ‚àÄi‚àà[n]for-allùëñdelimited-[]ùëõ\forall i\in[n]‚àÄ italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ]:

{arxiv}

5.3 Proof of Lemma 3.2

Before making use of [45, Corollary 5.2] to prove the upper-bound on eysubscriptùëíùë¶e_{y}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it is to be noted that the arguments of gùëîgitalic_g and g^^ùëî\hat{g}over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG, in the definition of eysubscriptùëíùë¶e_{y}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are different. Thus, we re-write eysubscriptùëíùë¶e_{y}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as ey=g^‚Å¢(p,x^)‚àíg‚Å¢(p,x^)+g‚Å¢(p,x^)‚àíg‚Å¢(p,h‚Å¢(p,d))subscriptùëíùë¶^ùëîùëù^ùë•ùëîùëù^ùë•ùëîùëù^ùë•ùëîùëù‚Ñéùëùùëëe_{y}=\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-g(p,\hat{x})+g(p,\hat{x})-g(p,h(p,d))italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) + italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) and note the following:

‚à•ey‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëíùë¶\displaystyle\lVert e_{y}\rVert‚à• italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚â§(a)‚Å¢‚à•g^‚Å¢(p,x^)‚àíg‚Å¢(p,x^)‚à•+‚à•g‚Å¢(p,h‚Å¢(p,d)+ex)‚àíg‚Å¢(p,h‚Å¢(p,d))‚à•ùëédelimited-‚à•‚à•^ùëîùëù^ùë•ùëîùëù^ùë•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëîùëù‚Ñéùëùùëësubscriptùëíùë•ùëîùëù‚Ñéùëùùëë\displaystyle\underset{(a)}{\leq}\lVert\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-{g}(p,\hat{x})\rVert% +\lVert g(p,h(p,d)+e_{x})-g(p,h(p,d))\rVertstart_UNDERACCENT ( italic_a ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ‚â§ end_ARG ‚à• over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) ‚à• + ‚à• italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) ‚à•
‚â§(b)‚Å¢‚à•g^‚Å¢(p,x^)‚àíg‚Å¢(p,x^)‚à•+‚à•‚àáxg‚ä§‚Å¢(p,h‚Å¢(p,d))‚Å¢ex‚à•+Œ±yùëèdelimited-‚à•‚à•^ùëîùëù^ùë•ùëîùëù^ùë•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscript‚àáùë•superscriptùëîtopùëù‚Ñéùëùùëësubscriptùëíùë•subscriptùõºùë¶\displaystyle\underset{(b)}{\leq}\lVert\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-{g}(p,\hat{x})\rVert% +\lVert\nabla_{x}g^{\top}(p,h(p,d))e_{x}\rVert+\alpha_{y}start_UNDERACCENT ( italic_b ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ‚â§ end_ARG ‚à• over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) ‚à• + ‚à• ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• + italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
‚â§(c)‚Å¢‚à•g^‚Å¢(p,x^)‚àíg‚Å¢(p,x^)‚à•+Mx‚Å¢œµx+Œ±y.ùëêdelimited-‚à•‚à•^ùëîùëù^ùë•ùëîùëù^ùë•subscriptùëÄùë•subscriptitalic-œµùë•subscriptùõºùë¶\displaystyle\underset{(c)}{\leq}\lVert\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-{g}(p,\hat{x})\rVert% +M_{x}\epsilon_{x}+\alpha_{y}.start_UNDERACCENT ( italic_c ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ‚â§ end_ARG ‚à• over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) ‚à• + italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

In (a)ùëé(a)( italic_a ), we make use of the identity x^=h‚Å¢(p,d)+ex^ùë•‚Ñéùëùùëësubscriptùëíùë•\hat{x}=h(p,d)+e_{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with the state estimation error exsubscriptùëíùë•e_{x}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined in Lemma 2. In (b)ùëè(b)( italic_b ), we use the Taylor series expansion on g‚Å¢(p,h‚Å¢(p,d)+ex)ùëîùëù‚Ñéùëùùëësubscriptùëíùë•g(p,h(p,d)+e_{x})italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) around xùë•xitalic_x. In (c)ùëê(c)( italic_c ), we use Assumption 2, i.e. g‚Å¢(p,x)ùëîùëùùë•g(p,x)italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) is MxsubscriptùëÄùë•M_{x}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-Lipshitz with respect to xùë•xitalic_x and the fact that the opinion estimation error is upper-bounded with ‚à•ex‚à•‚â§œµxdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëíùë•subscriptitalic-œµùë•\lVert e_{x}\rVert\leq\epsilon_{x}‚à• italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Lemma 2.

The existence of an upper-bound on ‚à•g^‚Å¢(p,x^)‚àíg‚Å¢(p,x^)‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•^ùëîùëù^ùë•ùëîùëù^ùë•\lVert\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-{g}(p,\hat{x})\rVert‚à• over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) ‚à• is similar to the one in Lemma 2. Thus, we directly make use of [46, Theorem 7] to state the following upper-bound ‚àÄi‚àà[n]for-allùëñdelimited-[]ùëõ\forall i\in[n]‚àÄ italic_i ‚àà [ italic_n ]:

where suppi‚ààùí≥p,i,xi‚ààùí≥x,i‚Å¢|gi‚Å¢(pi,xi)‚àíg^i‚Å¢(pi,xi)|formulae-sequencesubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùí≥ùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùí≥ùë•ùëñsupsubscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscript^ùëîùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\underset{p_{i}\in\mathcal{X}_{p,i},x_{i}\in\mathcal{X}_{x,i}}{\mathrm{sup}}|g% _{i}(p_{i},x_{i})-\hat{g}_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})|start_UNDERACCENT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG | italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | refers to the maximum training error on each user iùëñiitalic_i, œâgi‚Å¢(Œ≥y)subscriptùúîsubscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùõæùë¶\omega_{g_{i}}(\gamma_{y})italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) refers to the modulus of continuity of gisubscriptùëîùëñg_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on ùí¥ùí¥\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y, w0,isubscriptùë§0ùëñw_{0,i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the estimated bias weight w0subscriptùë§0w_{0}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the penultimate layer to the output layer of the neural network for user iùëñiitalic_i. It is now possible to state the following:
